article.title: Cell Type-Specific Imaging of Calcium Signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana Seedling Roots Using GCaMP3
funding: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA grants 80NSSC18K1462 and 80NSSC19KO129)
article.abstract: Cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) is a well-characterized second messenger in eukaryotic cells. An elevation in [Ca2+]cyt levels is one of the earliest responses in plant cells after exposure to a range of environmental stimuli.

sections.introduction: Calcium (Ca2+) plays a vital role as a second messenger system in plant development and stress response.
sections.methods: Each promoter was amplified from genomic DNA extracted from wild-type Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings using the Plant DNAzol Reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) (Table S1).
sections.results: To the best of our knowledge, plant lines expressing genetically encoded [Ca2+]cyt sensors that are available to the scientific community are driven by constitutive promoters.
sections.discussion: In this paper, we introduced a set of A. thaliana lines expressing the intensiometric [Ca2+]cyt reporter GCaMP3 targeted to specific root cell types.

article.insights_summary: We introduced a set of Arabidopsis thaliana lines expressing the intensiometric [Ca2+]cyt reporter GCaMP3 targeted to specific root cell types. Roots of these cell type specific GCaMP3 lines responded to chemical treatments such as ATP, glutamate, aluminum, and salt by exhibiting increases in [Ca2+]cyt-dependent CGaMP3 fluorescence.
